(2) Rathbun RE; Transport, Behavior, and Fate of Volatile Organic Compounds in Streams. USGS Professional Paper 1589, PB98-163397 (1998)
(3) Warneck P; Chemosphere 69: 347-361 (2007)
(4) Boublik T et al; The Vapour Pressures of Pure Substances, Amsterdam, The Netherlands: Elsevier Science Publ p. 87 (1984)
(5) Fan S, Scow KM; Appl Environ Microbiol 59: 1911-18 (1993)

(6) NITE; Chemical Risk Information Platform (CHRIP). Biodegradation and Bioconcentration. Tokyo, Japan: Natl Inst Tech Eval. Available from, as of Dec 12, 2016: https://www.safe.nite.go.jp/english/db.html

StringWithMarkup.String: TERRESTRIAL FATE: Based on a classification scheme(1), an average Koc value of 101, based on measurements in 32 soils(2), indicates that trichloroethylene is expected to have high mobility in soil(SRC). Volatilization of trichloroethylene from moist soil surfaces is expected to be an important fate process(SRC) given a Henry's Law constant of 9.02X10-3 atm-cu m/mole(3). Trichloroethylene is expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces(SRC) based upon a vapor pressure of 69 mm Hg at 25 °C(4). Trichloroethylene can exist in soil in the gas, liquid and adsorbed phases(5). The initial percentage of trichloroethylene in the gas (24, 52, 57%), liquid (5, 3, 4%) and adsorbed (71, 45, 39%) phases was determined in three soils, respectively: (Rindge, 11.2% organic matter, 35.4% moisture; Yolo, 2.2% organic matter, 11.7% moisture; Reiff, 1.4% organic matter, 13.9% moisture)(5). A 2.4% of theoretical BOD using activated sludge in the Japanese MITI test indicates that trichloroethylene is not readily biodegradable(6). Trichloroethylene is resistant to aerobic biodegradation although biodegradation may proceed cometabolically(5,7). Under anaerobic conditions, as might be seen in soil microsites, flooded soils or aquifer sites, trichloroethylene is slowly biodegraded via reductive dechlorination; the extent and rate of degradation is dependent upon the strength of the reducing environment(8). Anaerobic half-lives of 0.144 to 3.3 years have been reported(9).

Reference: (1) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)
(2) Rathbun RE; Transport, Behavior, and Fate of Volatile Organic Compounds in Streams. USGS Professional Paper 1589, NTIS PB98 163397 (1998)
(3) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 5-9, 15-1 to 15-29 (1990)
(4) Warneck P; Chemosphere 69: 347-361 (2007)
(5) Wakeham SG et al; Environ Sci Technol 17: 611-17 (1983)
(6) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)

(7) NITE; Chemical Risk Information Platform (CHRIP). Biodegradation and Bioconcentration. Tokyo, Japan: Natl Inst Tech Eval. Available from, as of Dec 12, 2016: https://www.safe.nite.go.jp/english/db.html
(8) Hopkins GD, McCarty PL; Environ Sci Technol 29: 1628-37 (1995)
(9) Semprini L et al; Ground Water 28: 715-27 (1990)
(10) Semprini L et al; Ground Water 29: 239-50 (1991)
(11) McCarty PL; Symp Nat Atten Chlor Org Ground Water USEPA/540/R-96/509 pp. 5-9 (1996)
(12) Jeffers PM et al; Environ Sci Technol 23: 965-969 (1989)
(13) Jeffers PM, Wolfe NL; Environ Toxicol Chem 17: 1066-1070 (1996)
(14) Mill T; Chemosphere 38: 1379-1390 (1999)

StringWithMarkup.String: AQUATIC FATE: Based on a classification scheme(1), an average Koc value of 101, based on measurements in 32 soils(2), indicates that trichloroethylene is not expected to adsorb to suspended solids and sediment(SRC). Volatilization from water surfaces is expected(3) based upon a Henry's Law constant of 9.02X10-3 atm-cu m/mole(4). Using this Henry's Law constant and an estimation method(3), volatilization half-lives for a model river and model lake are 3.5 hours and 4.6 days, respectively(SRC). Trichloroethylene volatilization half-lives from a mesocosm field experiment in Narragansett Bay ranged from 10.7 to 28 days(5). According to a classification scheme(6), BCFs of 17(3), 4-17(7) and 39(3) in bluegill sunfish, carp and rainbow trout, respectively, suggest bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low to moderate(SRC). A 2.4% of theoretical BOD using activated sludge in the Japanese MITI test indicates that trichloroethylene is not readily biodegradable(7). Trichloroethylene is resistant to biodegradation under aerobic conditions although cometabolic biodegradation has been reported under conditions where additional nutrients have been added(8-10). Under anaerobic conditions, as might be seen in sediments or groundwater, trichloroethylene is slowly biodegraded via reductive dechlorination; the extent and rate of degradation is dependent upon the strength of the reducing environment(11). Hydrolysis is not expected to be an important environmental fate process since the hydrolysis half-life of trichloroethylene at 25 °C has been approximated to be 1X10+5 to 1X10+6 years(12,13). Although trichloroethylene reacts with other photo-oxidants in surface waters exposed to sunlight, hydroxyl radicals are expected to be the dominant photo-oxidant in water(14). The indirect photolysis half-life of trichloroethylene in some surface waters may be as short as 50 days(14).

Reference: (1) Bidleman TF; Environ Sci Technol 22: 361-367 (1988)
(2) Boublik T et al; The Vapour Pressures of Pure Substances, Amsterdam, The Netherlands: Elsevier Science Publ p. 87 (1984)
(3) Atkinson R et al; Atmos. Chem. Phys. 8: 4141-4496 (2008). Available from, as of Dec 12, 2016: https://www.atmos-chem-phys.net/special_issue8.html

(4) NIST; NIST Chemistry WebBook. Trichloroethylene (79-01-6). NIST Gas Phase Kinetics Database No. 69, Feb 2015 Release. Washington, DC: US Sec Commerce. Available from, as of Dec 12, 2016: https://webbook.nist.gov
(5) Kao AS; J Air Waste Manage Assoc 44: 683-96 (1994)
(6) Gay BW et al; Environ Sci Tech 10: 58-67 (1976)
(7) Cupitt LT; Fate of Toxic and Hazardous Materials in the Air Environment USEPA-600/3-80-084 (1980)
(8) Ligocki MP et al; Atmos Environ 19: 1609-17 (1985)
(9) Fries E et al; Sci Total Environ 391: 269-77 (2008)
(10) Barrett AM, Nunn JF; British Journal of Anaesthesia 44: 306-312 (1972)
(11) Mill T; Chemosphere 38: 1379-1390 (1999)

StringWithMarkup.String: ATMOSPHERIC FATE: According to a model of gas/particle partitioning of semivolatile organic compounds in the atmosphere(1), trichloroethylene, which has a vapor pressure of 69 mm Hg at 25 °C(2), is expected to exist solely as a vapor in the ambient atmosphere. Vapor-phase trichloroethylene is degraded in the atmosphere by reaction with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals(SRC); the half-life for this reaction in air is estimated to be 8 days(SRC), calculated from its rate constant of 2.00X10-12 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(3). Vapor-phase trichloroethylene is also degraded by reaction with nitrate radicals and ozone; the half-lives for these reactions are estimated to be 111 and >190days(SRC), calculated from their respective rate constants of 2.90X10-16 and <5.0X10-20 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(4). Phosgene, dichloroacetyl chloride, chloroform and formyl chloride are formed from the reaction of trichloroethylene with hydroxyl radicals(5-7). Monitoring has detected trichloroethylene in rain and snow samples(8,9), therefore, trichloroethylene may be removed from the air by wet deposition(SRC). Trichloroethylene does not absorb at wavelengths >290 nm(10,11) and, therefore, is not expected to be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(SRC).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental biodegradation for this compound. Biodegradation is the breakdown of organic matter by microorganisms, such as bacteria and fungi.  An important measure of biodegradability of wastewater is the biochemical oxygen demand (BOD), which is the amount of dissolved oxygen (DO) needed (i.e. demanded) by aerobic biological organisms to break down organic material present in a given water sample at certain temperature over a specific time period.

Reference: (1) El-Farham YH et al; Wat Res Research 34: 437-45 (1998)
(2) Fan S, Scow KM; Appl Environ Microbiol 59: 1911-18 (1993)
(3) Enzien MV et al; Appl Environ Microbiol 60: 2200-4 (1994)
(4) Anderson TA, Walton BT; Environ Toxicol Chem 14: 2041-2047 (1995)

(5) NITE; Chemical Risk Information Platform (CHRIP). Biodegradation and Bioconcentration. Tokyo, Japan: Natl Inst Tech Eval. Available from, as of Dec 12, 2016: https://www.safe.nite.go.jp/english/db.html

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: Under aerobic conditions, trichloroethylene is biodegraded only in the presence of another compound that can support microbial growth in a process called cometabolism; biodegradation is generally complete and vinyl chloride is not produced(1). Indigenous sources of carbon associated with soil organic matter did not support cometabolic degradation of trichloroethylene in a soil study(2). Trichloroethylene was aerobically degraded in a column composed of aquifer sediments by 9 and 87% during the first 6.5 months and the following 3.5 months, respectively; the initial loss of 9% may have been due to abiotic losses such as adsorption or volatilization(3). cis-1,2-Dichloroethylene was reported as the major product of trichloroethylene degradation in this experiment(3). Trichloroethylene was mineralized by up to 30% in microcosms containing soil and vegetation from a former trichloroethylene-contaminated site(4). Microcosms which were either non-vegetated or sterile showed mineralization of trichloroethylene, measured as CO2 production, of 10-15% and 5-10%, respectively(4). Trichloroethylene, present at 100 mg/L, reached 2.4% of its theoretical BOD in 2 weeks using an activated sludge inoculum at 30 mg/L in the Japanese MITI test which classified the compound as not readily biodegradable(5).

Reference: (1) Parker WJ et al; Wat Environ Res 65: 58-65 (1993)
(2) Clapp LW et al; Water Environ Res 66: 153-60 (1994)
(3) Scheutz C et al; J Environ Qual 33: 61-71 (2004)
(4) Carr CS et al; Environ Sci Technol 34:1088-94 (2000)
(5) El-Farhan YH et al; J Environ Qual 29: 778-86 (2000)

StringWithMarkup.String: AEROBIC: In a municipal activated sludge plant, 47.3, 47.8, and 0.0% of the influent trichloroethylene concentration (at 40.7 ug/L) was biodegraded, stripped and found in the waste sludge, respectively (effluent concentration of 2.0 ug/L)(1). Two laboratory scale activated sludge reactors (AS-L, AS-H) and 2 biological aerated filter reactors (BAF-L, BAF-H) under high- and low-loaded conditions were used to study the removal of trichloroethylene during wastewater treatment(2). The average influent concentration was 32.1 ug/L; effluent concentrations for AS-L, AS-H, BAF-L, and BAF-H were 5.3, 6.1, 2.3, and 9.7 ug/L, respectively(2). Loss due to biodegradation was 0, 0, 58, and 3% influent loadings, respectively, while loss due to stripping was 66, 85, 34, and 67% influent loadings, respectively(2). Trichloroethylene had a biodegradation rate of 0.057 ug/g soil/hr in soil from Skellingsted landfill in Holback, Denmark, incubated with methane(3). Trichloroethylene has a reported first order dechlorination rate of 0.27/hr(4). High concentrations of trichloroethylene inhibits aerobic degradation of toluene and becomes toxic to aerobes(5).

Reference: (1) Nielson PH et al; Chemosphere 25: 449-62 (1992)
(2) McCarty PL; pp. 5-9 in Symp Nat Atten Chlor Org Ground Water USEPA/540/R-96/509 (1996)
(3) Lendvay JM et al; Environ Sci Technol 32: 3472-78 (1998)

StringWithMarkup.String: In situ microcosm studies were conducted in both polluted aerobic and anaerobic and in unpolluted aerobic aquifer conditions in the Vejen City landfill; trichloroethylene was not degraded under either oxygen condition over a 90-day period(1). Trichloroethylene is reductively dechlorinated forming cis-1,2-dichloroethylene initially, then vinyl chloride and possibly ethene and ethane depending on the strength of the reducing environment(2). Under iron or sulfate-reducing conditions, cis-1,2-dichloroethylene is the major metabolite of trichloroethylene biodegradation while ethene is the major metabolite under methanogenic conditions(3).

Reference: (1) Johnston JJ et al; J Contam Hydrol 23: 263-83 (1996)
(2) Lige JE et al; pp. 313-320 in Biorem Chlor Solvents, Pap Int In Situ On-Site Bioreclam Symp. 3rd. Hinchee RE et al, eds. Columbus, OH: Battelle Press (1995)
(3) Martin M, Imbrigiotta TE; pp. 109-15 in USEPA Symp Natural Atten Ground Water, Denver, CO EPA/600/R-94/162 (1994)
(4) Wilson JT et al; in Symp Nat Atten Chlorin Org Ground Water, USEPA/540/R-96/509 (1996)
(5) Ehlke TA, Imbrigiotta TE; in Symp Nat Atten Chlor Org Ground Water. Hyatt Regency Dallas. Dallas, TX. USEPA EPA/540/R-96/509 (1996)
(6) Nielsen PH et al; J Contam Hydrol 20: 51-66 (1995)

StringWithMarkup.String: ANAEROBIC: Biodegradation rates for trichloroethylene in anaerobic aquifer microcosm studies were reported as follows: Wilder's Grove, NC landfill - methanogenic, lag phase of <41 to >300 days, degradation complete within 40 to 110 days once started(1); Dover Air Force Base, DE - methanogenic, half-lives of 57 and 267 days for 2 locations at site(2). A number of studies have been conducted at the Picatinny Arsenal in New Jersey(3-5). These reports indicated that biodegradation of trichloroethylene proceeded with a first-order rate constant of 0.001 to 0.02 per week(3) with half-lives of 1.1, 1.65, and 3.3 years being reported(4); a first-order rate constant of 0.004 to 0.035 per week was also reported(5). Biodegradation half-lives at other sites in the US were reported as follows: Tibbetts Road Superfund site, NH - half-lives of 0.188 years and 0.144 years(4); St. Joseph, MI - half-lives of 0.385 and 0.58 years; and Traverse City, MI - half-life of 0.385 years(4). Trichloroethylene was incubated in 4 methanogenic microcosms modeling the leachate plume of the Vejen Landfill, Denmark, with no degradation observed over 140-180 days)(6).
For more Environmental Biodegradation (Complete) data for Trichloroethylene (7 total), please visit the HSDB record page.

Section.Description: Abiotic degradation is a process by which a chemical substance is broken down into smaller molecules by non-biotic means (e.g., hydrolysis, photolysis, and oxidation).

Reference: (1) Atkinson R et al; Atmos. Chem. Phys. 8: 4141-4496 (2008). Available from, as of Dec 12, 2016: https://www.atmos-chem-phys.net/special_issue8.html
(2) US EPA; Estimation Program Interface (EPI) Suite. Ver. 4.1. Nov, 2012. Available from, as of Dec 12, 2016, 2016: https://www2.epa.gov/tsca-screening-tools/

StringWithMarkup.String: The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of trichloroethylene with photochemically-produced hydroxyl radicals has been measured as 2.0X10-12 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(1). This corresponds to an atmospheric half-life of about 8 days at an atmospheric concentration of 5X10+5 hydroxyl radicals per cu cm(2). Reaction with hydroxyl radical yields phosgene, dichloroacetyl chloride, chloroform and formyl chloride(3-5). The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of trichloroethylene with night-time nitrate radicals is 2.90X10-16 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(6). This corresponds to an atmospheric half-life of about 111 days at an atmospheric concentration of 2.5X10+8 nitrate radicals per cu cm(7). The rate constant for the vapor-phase reaction of trichloroethylene with ozone is <5.0X10-20 cu cm/molecule-sec at 25 °C(6). This corresponds to an atmospheric half-life of >230 days at an atmospheric concentration of 7X10+11 ozone molecules per cu cm(2). Ozone depletion potential values for trichloroethylene range from 0.083 to 0.13 relative to CFC-11(8). Trichloroethylene does not absorb at wavelengths >290 nm(9,10) and, therefore, is not expected to be susceptible to direct photolysis by sunlight(SRC).

Reference: (1) Callahan MA et al; Water-Related Environmental Fate of 129 Priority Pollutants - Vol II USEPA-440/4-79-029B (1979)
(2) Jeffers PM et al; Environ Sci Technol 23: 965-969 (1989)
(3) Jeffers PM, Wolfe NL; Environ Toxicol Chem 17: 1066-1070 (1996)
(4) Dilling WL; Environ Sci Tech 9: 833-8 (1975)
(5) Buxton GV et al; J Phys Chem Ref Data 17: 513-882 (1988)
(6) Mill T et al; Science 207: 886-887 (1980)
(7) Mill T; Chemosphere 38: 1379-1390 (1999)

StringWithMarkup.String: Trichloroethylene is not hydrolyzed by water under normal conditions(1). Based on hydrolysis studies, the hydrolysis half-life of trichloroethylene at 25 °C has been approximated to be 1X10+5 to 1X10+6 years(2,3). Slow indirect photo-oxidation of trichloroethylene in water has been observed in laboratory studies(4). The rate constant for the reaction of hydroxyl radicals with trichloroethylene in aqueous solutions at pH 6.5 is 4.2X10+9 L/mol-sec(5); this corresponds to an aquatic half-life of 191 days at an aquatic concentration of 1X10-17 hydroxyl radicals per liter(2). Although trichloroethylene reacts with other photo-oxidants in surface waters exposed to sunlight, hydroxyl radicals are expected to be the dominant photo-oxidant(7). The indirect photolysis half-life of trichloroethylene in some surface waters may be as short as 50 days(7).

Section.Description: This section provides information on environmental bioconcentration for this compound.  Bioconcentration is the accumulation of a chemical in or on an organism when the source of chemical is solely water. Bioconcentration is a term that was created for use in the field of aquatic toxicology. Bioconcentration can also be defined as the process by which a chemical concentration in an aquatic organism exceeds that in water as a result of exposure to a waterborne chemical.

Reference: (1) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 5-9 (1990)

(2) NITE; Chemical Risk Information Platform (CHRIP). Biodegradation and Bioconcentration. Tokyo, Japan: Natl Inst Tech Eval. Available from, as of Dec 12, 2016: https://www.safe.nite.go.jp/english/db.html
(3) Freitag D et al; Chemosphere 14: 1589-1616 (1985)
(4) Franke C et al; Chemosphere 29: 1501-14 (1994)
(5) Rathbun RE; Transport, Behavior, and Fate of Volatile Organic Compounds in Streams, US Geological Survey Prof Paper 1589, USGS, NTIS PB98-163-397 (1998)
(6) Dickson AG, Riley JP; Marine Pollut Bull 7: 167-9 (1976)
(7) Pearson CR, McConnell G; Proc Roy Soc London Ser B 189: 305-32 (1975)

StringWithMarkup.String: BCF values of 17 and 39 were measured in bluegill sunfish and rainbow trout, respectively(1). In carp (Cyprinus carpio), BCF values of 4.3-17 and 4.0-16.0 were reported for trichloroethylene at 70 and 7 ug/L, after 6 week of exposure(2). A BCF of 90 was measured in golden ide fish (Leuciscus idus melanotus) after a 3-day static exposure(3). According to a classification scheme(4), these BCF values suggest bioconcentration in aquatic organisms is low to moderate(SRC). A BCF of 302 was measured in a green alga(5). Marine monitoring data suggest only moderate bioconcentration (2-25 times) of trichloroethylene(6,7).

Section.Description: Sorption to soils and sediments is an important factor on the transport and fate of organic contaminants in the environment.  The soil/water adsorption coefficient, also known as solid-water distribution coefficient (Kd), measures the amount of chemical substance adsorbed onto soil per amount of water.  Since adsorption occurs predominantly by partition into the soil organic matter, it is more useful to normalize the Kd value to the organic carbon content of a soil and express the distribution coefficient in Koc (organic carbon normalized distribution coefficient).  The greater the Kd (or Koc) value, the less likely a chemical will leach or contribute to runoff.  A very high value means it is strongly adsorbed onto soil and organic matter and does not move throughout the soil.

Reference: (1) Bahnick DA, Doucette WJ; Chemosphere 17: 1703-15 (1988)
(2) Borisover MD, Graber ER; Chemosphere 34: 1761-76 (1997)
(3) Brigmon RL et al; J Soil Contam 7: 433-53 (1998)
(4) Sahoo D, Smith JA; Environ Sci Technol 31: 1910-15 (1997)
(5) Chiou CT, Kile DE; Environ Sci Technol 32: 338-43 (1998)
(6) Rathbun RE; Transport, Behavior, and Fate of Volatile Organic Compounds in Streams. USGS Professional Paper 1589, NTIS PB98 163397 (1998)
(7) Carmichael LM et al; J Environ Qual 28: 888-97 (1999)
(8) Fuentes HR et al; Haz Waste Haz Mater 7: 347-59 (1990)
(9) Grathwohl P; Environ Sci Technol 24: 1687-93 (1990)
(10) Mouvet C et al; J Hydrol 149: 163-82 (1993)
(11) Pavlostathis SG, Jaglal K; Environ Sci Technol 25: 274-79 (1991)
(12) Swann RL et al; Res Rev 85: 17-28 (1983)

StringWithMarkup.String: Measured Koc values of 100(1), 110(2), 72 to 180 (organic matter of <1.0 to 5%)(3), 66(4), 49 (peat soil)(5), 72, 96, 142(6) and 58 (peat soil)(6) have been reported for trichloroethylene. The average Kd value for trichloroethylene, applied with a mixture of organic compounds to low organic, subsurface soils was 0.093(7). Kp values of 1.06 (coarse sand), 0.67 (silty-clay loam), 0.17 (fine sand), 6.0 (podzolic sand, % organic content 0.90), 4.2 (sandy soil, % organic content 6.07), 32 (peat soil, % organic content 59.3) and 1.24 (Bandelier turf, % organic content 0.11) have been reported for trichloroethylene(8). A study of 32 soils (foc range of 0.0012 to 0.31) reported an average Koc of 101(6). Koc values for trichloroethylene in a loess sand, weathered shale, and unweathered shale were 123, 363, and 2691, respectively(9). In nine different soils (foc ranging from 0.13 to 1.2%), Koc values ranged from 69 to 209(10). Trichloroethylene from soil samples which had been contaminated for 18 years was found to be resistant to desorption, requiring extended periods of time for equilibration(11). According to a classification scheme(12), these Koc values suggest that trichloroethylene is expected to have high mobility in soil. Trichloroethylene partitioned from an aqueous solution of Bandelier tuff under equilibrium conditions to 64-81% in water, 16-23% in vapor phase, and 2-20% in the tuff(8).

Reference: (1) Benker E et al; in Proc Prague Conf IAHS Publ No 225(Groundwater Quality: Remediation and Protection): 61-9 (1995)
(2) Bourg ACM et al; J Hydrol 149: 187-207 (1993)
(3) Broholm K et al; Environ Sci Technol 33: 681-90 (1999)
(4) Fan S, Scow KM; Appl Environ Microbiol 59: 1911-18 (1993)
(5) Shimizu Y et al; Wat Sci Tech 26: 79-87 (1992)

StringWithMarkup.String: In a field groundwater test, no sorption of trichloroethylene onto organic carbon or mineral surfaces present in the sand aquifer was observed(1). Two field studies, both of shallow confined aquifers, reported retardation factors from 5 to 9 (foc = 0.11%) and 11.4 (foc = 0.11%)(2). In undisturbed rock cores from the Coventry sandstone aquifer system (foc = 0.7 to 0.8%), trichloroethylene had a retardation factor of <3 indicating that it should migrate readily with water(2). Other column studies using sand aquifer material reported retardation factors from 1.1 to 4.7(2). A retardation factor of 1.1 was reported for trichloroethylene in the aquifer underlying the Canadian Forces Base in Borden, Ontario(3). The initial percentage of trichloroethylene in the gas (24, 52, 57%), liquid (5, 3, 4%) and adsorbed (71, 45, 39%) phases was determined in three soils, respectively (Rindge, 11.2% organic matter, 35.4% moisture; Yolo, 2.2% organic matter, 11.7% moisture; Reiff, 1.4% organic matter, 13.9% moisture)(4). Sorption in these soils followed reversible, linear sorption isotherms(4). Sorption of trichloroethylene vapor to soil is possible; linear sorption coefficients of trichloroethylene from the vapor phase were about one to four orders of magnitude greater than those from the aqueous phase based on studies using six different US EPA soils and sediments under varying moisture contents(5).

Section.Description: Volatilization of chemicals from water/soil is the transfer of the chemical as a gas through the water-air or soil-air interface under environmental conditions

Reference: (1) Warneck P; Chemosphere 69: 347-361 (2007)
(2) Lyman WJ et al; Handbook of Chemical Property Estimation Methods. Washington, DC: Amer Chem Soc pp. 15-1 to 15-29 (1990)
(3) Dilling WL; Environ Sci Technol 9: 833-8 (1975)
(4) Wakeham SG et al; Environ Sci Technol 17: 611-7 (1983)
(5) Boublik T et al; The Vapour Pressures of Pure Substances, Amsterdam, The Netherlands: Elsevier Science Publ p. 87 (1984)
(6) Smith RL; Ann Occup Hyg 45: 437-445 (2001). Available from, as of Dec 13. 2016: https://annhyg.oxfordjournals.org/content/45/6/437.full.pdf

StringWithMarkup.String: The Henry's Law constant for trichloroethylene is 9.85X10-3 atm-cu m/mole at 25 °C(1). This Henry's Law constant indicates that trichloroethylene is expected to volatilize rapidly from water surfaces(2). Based on this Henry's Law constant, the volatilization half-life from a model river (1 m deep, flowing 1 m/sec, wind velocity of 3 m/sec)(2) is estimated as 3.5 hours(SRC). The volatilization half-life from a model lake (1 m deep, flowing 0.05 m/sec, wind velocity of 0.5 m/sec)(2) is estimated as 4.6 days(SRC). Half-lives of evaporation from laboratory water surfaces (distilled water) have been reported to be on the order of several minutes to hours, depending upon the turbulence(2-3). Half-lives of trichloroethylene from an experimental marine ecosystem (MERL) under field conditions and during periods when volatilization appeared to dominate ranged from 10.7 to 28 days; turbulence is expected to be greater in open water resulting in even faster half-lives(4). Trichloroethylene's Henry's Law constant indicates that volatilization from moist soil surfaces is expected to occur(SRC). Trichloroethylene is expected to volatilize from dry soil surfaces(SRC) based upon a vapor pressure of 69 mm Hg(5). The evaporation rate of trichloroethylene from a liquid pool (75x20x5 mm) at 27 °C was 1.80 mmol/sq m/sec (ethanol was 3.00 mmol/sq m/sec)(6).

Reference: (1) Hughes BM et al; pp. 81-88 in Subsurface Contamination by Immiscible Fluids. Weyer, ed. Rotterdam, The Netherlands: Balkema, ISBN 90-6191-1753 (1992)
(2) Fuentes HR et al; J Environ Qual 20: 215-21 (1991)
(3) Hutter GM et al; Wat Environ Res 64: 69-77 (1992)
(4) Culver TB et al; Wat Res Research 27: 2259-70 (1991)

StringWithMarkup.String: The transport behavior of trichloroethylene vapor in a section of unsaturated sands and silts at a field site in Borden, Ontario was studied(1). Movement of trichloroethylene vapor through unsaturated layers was shown to be lateral based on the density-induced advective flow of the contaminated soil gas(1). Gas-phase diffusion coefficients for trichloroethylene in turf soils with varying moisture content were measured(2). Under wet conditions (12-15% moisture), diffusion coefficients of 0.0022-0.0067 and 0.0067-0.0070 sq cm/sec were determined for trichloroethylene; under dry conditions (1-3% moisture), diffusion coefficients of 0.0211-0.0230 and 0.0237-0.0292 sq cm/sec were determined(2). Soil diffusion coefficients were measured for trichloroethylene at 3 different soil porosities (0.29 to 0.43); values ranged from 0.254X10-3 to 1.986X10-3 sq cm/sec, with the larger values associated with higher soil porosity levels(3). The total amount of trichloroethylene that volatilizes in 100 days may be reduced from 84.6% volatilized without vapor sorption to 73.2% in a soil with increasing water content with depth, based on a flexible finite element transport model(4). Using the same model, vapor sorption enhanced the rate of volatilization in 100 days for a soil with low water content at depth from 72.4% without vapor sorption to 90.3% with vapor sorption(4). Very dry soil conditions combined with a soil type having strong vapor sorption characteristics may significantly retard the transport of trichloroethylene in the vapor phase(4).

Section.Description: Concentrations of this chemical in water in various stages of hydrologic cycle (e.g., drinking water, ground water, surface water, and rain/snow).

StringWithMarkup.String: GROUNDWATER: Trichloroethylene was the most frequently detected organic chemical and in highest concentration; 28% of wells from 8 states sampled positive with a max concentration reported at 35,000 ppb(2); 38.5% of 13 US cities tested positive with a mean concentration of 29.72 ppb and a range of 0.2-125 ppb(1). A study in New Jersey of 670 wells showed that 1.8% and 4.0% of wells had concentrations >100 ppb and >10 ppb, respectively(3). 13% of groundwater alluvial wells monitored in Denver metropolitan in 1993 contained trichloroethylene (max concentration 2 ug/L)(4). Trichloroethylene was not detected in ground water from the Salt River alluvium in Phoenix, AZ(5). An assessment of untreated ambient groundwater in the US from 1985 to 1995 was conducted as part of the National Water Quality Assessment Program; trichloroethylene was detected in 11.6% of 406 urban wells and 1.6% of 2542 rural wells(6). Trichloroethylene was detected in 4.2% of 954 community water systems that supply drinking water in all 50 states, Puerto Rico, Native American Lands, and the District of Columbia in a nation wide study done May 3, 1999 to Oct 23, 2000(7). Trichloroethylene was detected in 10.1% of 208 groundwater well samples collected in urban areas by the National Water Quality Assessment Program at a maximum concentration of 230 ug/L (reporting limit 0.2 ug/L; 3 wells exceeded MCL or health advisory level)(8). Of 210 urban wells and springs sampled during the USGS National Water Quality Assessment Program, 10% contained trichloroethylene(9). Ground water concentrations of trichloroethylene from Richmond, CA were reported as 0.02-2553 uM in Feb 2001(10). Trichloroethylene was measured at the Department of Energy's Savannah River site in SC with concentrations of 149.9 ug/L at the source, 0.02 ug/L upgrade, and 0.10 and 10.10 ug/L downgrade of the source(11). Groundwater samples collected from beneath an active landfill in Orange County, Florida, in 1989/1990 and 1992/1993 contained trichloroethylene at below detection to 9.21 ug/L and 0.09 to 0.54 ug/L, respectively(12). Trichloroethylene was detected at 30 of 49 Superfund sites citing municipal well contamination, distributed in 21 US states(13).

Reference: (1) Barker JF; Water Poll Res J Canada 22: 33-48 (1987)
(2) Abe A; Sci Total Environ 227: 41-7 (1999)
(3) Assmuth TW, Strandberg T; Water Air Soil Pollut 69: 179-99 (1993)
(4) Zoeteman BCJ et al; Sci Total Environ 21: 187-202 (1981)
(5) Tase N; Environ Geol Water Sci 20: 15-20 (1992)
(6) Broholm K et al; Chemosphere 60: 1555-64 (2005)
(7) Juhler RK, Felding G; Water Air Soil Pollut 149: 145-61 (2003)
(8) Kuo MCT et al; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 65: 654-9 (2000)
(9) Palacios M et al; Water Res 34: 1002-16 (2000)
(10) Rosell M et al; Environ Toxicol Chem 24: 2785-95 (2005)

StringWithMarkup.String: GROUNDWATER: Trichloroethylene concentrations measured at 6 landfill sites in southern Ontario ranged from below the method detection limit (not given)(3 of 6 sites) to 21 ug/L(1). 10 of 27 groundwater sites in Kanagawa Prefecture, Japan (samples collected 1995-1998), contained trichloroethylene at concentrations from <0.1 to 220 ug/L(2). In a study of groundwater beneath 27 Swedish landfills, median and maximum concentrations of <0.1 and 5.0 ug/L trichloroethylene were reported(3). Groundwater samples in the Netherlands collected from 1976-78, at 232 pumping stations, showed that 67% were positive (>0.01 ppb) for trichloroethylene(4). Trichloroethylene was detected a measurable levels in 26 of 1,083 shallow wells and 14 of 277 deep wells sampled in 15 cities in Japan in 1983(5). Trichloroethylene was detected in Denmark groundwaters in an industrial area of Frederiksborg at <0.1-1.1 ug/L in samples taken in 1999 and in Copenhagen at concentrations of <0.01-1.5 ug/L(6). Trichloroethylene was detected in 3.6% of 3318 samples from the Danish National Groundwater Monitoring Program conducted from 1993 to 2001 with a maximum concentration of 3.7 ug/L(7). Trichloroethylene was detected in 7-8% of 214 samples from 30 industrial sites in samples taken in 1999 in Taiwan(8). Trichloroethylene was not detected in treated groundwater samples from the European Union (Belgium, France, Germany, Spain, The Netherlands, Italy)(9). A 2 year study (Nov 2001 to Nov 2003) of 14 wells resulted in 28 of 96 samples testing positive for trichloroethylene at concentrations of 0.02-0.06 ug/L from Dusseldorf, Germany(10).

Reference: (1) Brass HJ et al; Drinking Water Qual Enhancement Source Prot pp. 393-416 (1977)
(2) Council on Environmental Quality Contamination of Groundwater by Toxic Organic Chemicals pp. 26-34 (1980)

(7) ATSDR; Toxicological Profile for Trichloroethylene. Atlanta, GA: Agency for Toxic Substances and Disease Registry, US Public Health Service (2014). Available from, as of Dec 12, 2016: https://www.atsdr.cdc.gov/toxprofiles/index.asp

StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: 28 of 113 US public water supplies tested positive for trichloroethylene during 1976-1977 monitoring with a mean concentration of 2.1 ppb(1). Trichloroethylene was found in finished groundwater in 36% of 25 US cities at a mean concentration of 6.76 ppb, range 0.11-53.0 ppb(2). Samples from the Love Canal, Niagara Falls, NY showed that 7 of 9 samples tested positive, with a concentration range of 10-250 parts/trillion(3). 466 random samples of finished groundwater showed that 6.4% pos, 1 ppb median concentration, 78 ppb max concentration(4). State data, 2894 samples, showed that 28.0% tested positive for trichloroethylene from a trace to 35,000 ppb; in the US National Screening Program, of 142 samples, 25.4% tested positive with a trace to 53 ppb and in a Community Water Supply Survey, 3.3% of 452 samples were positive, with a concentration range of 0.5-210 ppb(5). Tap water samples taken in Phoenix, AZ in 1997 and 1998 contained 0.1 ug/L of trichloroethylene(6). Between 4.5 and 18% of the drinking water supply sources in the United States that are tested on a yearly basis by the EPA have measurable levels of trichloroethylene (based on 1998-2005 monitoring data)(7); these levels are typically <30 ppb(7). In 2005, 46,937 samples from groundwater supplied PWS (public water systems) had a 4.9% positive detection of trichloroethylene with mean, median and maximum concentrations of 3.33, 1.10 and 159 ppb respectively(7). In 2005, 12,702 samples from surface water supplied PWS (public water systems) had a 15% positive detection of trichloroethylene with mean, median and maximum concentrations of 5.40, 1.60 and 50 ppb respectively(7).

Reference: (1) Skender L et al; Arch Environ Hlth 49: 445-51 (1994)
(2) Tancrede MV, Yanagisawa Y; J Air Waste Manage Assoc 40: 1658-63 (1990)
(3) Vedrina-Dragojevic I, Dragojevic D; Sci Total Environ 203: 253-59 (1997)
(4) Canter LW, Sabatini DA; Intern J Environ Studies 46: 35-57 (1994)
(5) Wallace LA et al; Atmos Environ 22: 2141-63 (1988)
(6) Al-Mudhaf HF et al; Sci Total Environ 407: 1658-1668 (2009)

StringWithMarkup.String: DRINKING WATER: Trichloroethylene was detected in drinking water from Zagreb, Croatia at concentrations of <0.05-22.93 ug/L (sampling dates not reported)(1). Trichloroethylene tap water concentrations ranged from 0.03 to 2.1 ug/L according to the EPA's National Organics Monitoring Survey, published in 1977(2). Concentrations of trichloroethylene in groundwater before and after treatment from June 1995 to May 1996 at a water-pumping station in Zagreb, Croatia, ranged from 5.05-12.90 ug/L (mean = 8.55 ug/L) and 2.16 to 15.29 ug/L (mean = 8.53 ug/L), respectively(3). The Eau Clair Municipal Well field, WI, supplies drinking water to 57,600 residents; concentrations of trichloroethylene in water samples at this site ranged from 0.02 to 13 ug/L(4). This is currently listed as a Superfund site(4). Trichloroethylene was measurable in 8, 12, and 66% of collected drinking water samples in Los Angeles (Jan/Feb 1984), Los Angeles (May 1984), and Contra Costa (June 1984), respectively(5). Trichloroethylene was detected in only one sample of bottled drinking water collected in Kuwait between 2003-2005 (0.9% of all samples) at a concentration of 0.13 ug/L(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: Landfill gas at seven U.K. waste disposal sites in 1994-1995 contained trichloroethylene at <0.1 (4 sites) to 152 mg/cu m(1). Gas samples from 3 old and 1 active municipal landfills in Southern Finland contained trichloroethylene at average concentrations of 0.1 to 5.25 mg/cu m and a maximum concentration of 13 mg/cu m(2). Average trichloroethylene concentrations of 710 and 2079 ppbV were measured in samples of landfill gas(3). Emissions of trichloroethylene from hazardous waste incinerators in the US were estimated as 81.8 ng/L or 0.7 tons/yr(4). Stationary source emissions of 2640 tons/yr trichloroethylene were reported for The Netherlands in 1980(5). Landfill gas from 6 abandoned hazardous waste sites and 1 sanitary landfill contained trichloroethylene at mean concentrations of 0.08 to 2.43 ppbV and an overall maximum value of 12.3 ppbV(6). Emissions from a municipal waste incineration plant contained trichloroethylene at 4.0 ug/cu m(7). Trichloroethylene was reported in the flue gas from the combustion of pulverized coal at minimum and maximum concentrations of 4.747X10-7 and 5.685X10-7 lb/10+6 Btu, respectively(8). The combustion of waste plastics containing vinyl chloride polymer in an incinerator resulted in concentrations of trichloroethylene in the exhaust gas of 47-82 ug/cu m, depending on the combustion and exit chamber temperatures(9). Pyrolysis of military HC smokepots resulted in the production of trichloroethylene(10). Emissions from coal-fired power stations contained trichloroethylene at concentrations of 5.7 ug/N-cu m; the concentration in coal is 0.02 ug/g(11). Diesel engines are reported to emit 4.5 ug/N-cu m(11). Trichloroethylene was identified in the leachate plume of the municipal landfill in Norman, OK from samples taken Nov 1995 to April 1996(12).

Reference: (1) Hites RA et al; ACS Symp Ser 94: 63-90 (1979)
(2) USEPA; Treatability Manual pp. I.12.23-3 USEPA-600/2-82-001A (1981)

StringWithMarkup.String: Trichloroethylene was detected but not quantified in wastewater in vicinity of a specialty chemicals plant(1). Industries with mean trichloroethylene concentrations greater than 75 ppb: paint and ink formulation, electrical/electronic components, and rubber processing mean range, 7-530 ppb, maximum range 3-1600 ppb(2). As of 1985, concentration results of trichloroethylene reported in the USEPA STORET database are as follows: 1,480 data points, 19.6% pos, 5.0 ppb median(3). Groundwater samples at 178 CERCLA hazardous waste disposal sites were 51.3% pos(4). Trichloroethylene was detected in MN municipal solid waste landfills: leachates from 6 sites, 83.3% pos, 0.7-125 ppb; contaminated groundwater (by inorganic indices), 13 sites, 69.2% pos, 0.2-144 ppb; other groundwater (apparently not contaminated as indicated by inorganic indices), 7 sites, 28.6% pos, 0.2-6.8 ppb(5). Trichloroethylene was detected in 6% of 86 urban runoff samples from 4 of 19 different cities at 0.3-10 ug/L(6). Primary sludge from seven US publicly owned treatment works contained trichloroethylene at 35-284 ug/L(7). Bleaching effluent from 3 different kraft pulp mills in Finland contained trichloroethylene at concentrations of 0.1 to 0.7 ug/L(8). Trichloroethylene has been identified in spent chlorination and alkali extraction liquors from pulp bleaching(9). Effluent from 4 wastewater treatment plants in the Great Lakes basin contained trichloroethylene at concentrations of <1 to 1 ppb(10). Concentration of trichloroethylene in sewage sludge generally ranges from 1 to 10 mg/kg dry weight(11). Leachate samples from 5 hazardous waste landfills and 4 sanitary landfills contained trichloroethylene at concentrations of 30 to 9500 ug/L and 2.3 to 7.9 ug/L, respectively(12).

Reference: (1) Zhu H et al; J Air Waste Manage Assoc 49: 434-43 (1999)
(2) Derwent RG; in Volatile Org Compds in the Atmos. Hester RE, Harrison RM, eds. Cambridge, UK: Royal Soc Chem. Issues Environ Sci Technol 4: 1-15 (1995)
(3) Stubin AI et al; Water Environ Res 68: 1037-44 (1996)
(4) Mayer GJ et al; Wat Environ Res 66: 140-44 (1994)
(5) Roy WR; pp. 411-46 in Contam Groundwaters. Adriano DC et al, eds. Northwood, UK: Sci Rev (1994)
(6) Eitzer BD; Environ Sci Technol 29: 896-902 (1995)

StringWithMarkup.String: Off-gas from a conventional activated sludge treatment facility contained trichloroethylene at average concentrations of 175, 86, and 242 mg/cu m for three different weeks of operation in 1995/1996(1). Trichloroethylene represented 1.1% of the total mass distribution of different species emitted in 1990 from the United Kingdom(2). Influent and effluent samples collected from the 14 water pollution control plants (11 with full secondary treatment) in New York City between 1989 and 1993 contained trichloroethylene at 1-46 ug/L (27% of 84) and 2-3 ug/L (7% of 84), respectively(3). Emissions of trichloroethylene from wastewater treatment plants in Los Angeles, CA were 366, 12, 3, and 5 kg/yr for Hyperion, Terminal Island, Tillman, and LA-Glendale plants, respectively(4). Concentrations of trichloroethylene in municipal landfill leachate ranged from 1 to 15 mg/L; concentrations in landfill gases ranged from 1.2 to 175 mg/cu m (median 0.66 mg/cu m)(5). Trichloroethylene was emitted from 8 municipal solid waste composting facilities at a maximum concentration of 1300 ug/cu m; fresh, mid-aged, old, and curing compost contained trichloroethylene at average concentrations of 98, 3, 3, and 2 ug/cu m, respectively(6).

Reference: (1) Pratt GC et al; Environ Sci Technol 38: 1949-59 (2004)
(2) Barkley J et al; Biomed Mass Spectrom 7: 139-47 (1980)
(3) Pellizzari ED; Environ Sci Technol 16: 781-5 (1982)

StringWithMarkup.String: Calculated trichloroethylene release rates measured from 23 locations in Minneapolis/St Paul in 1999 were 1, 5, and 87 metric tons/year from consumer and commercial solvents, landfills, and publicly owned water treatment works, respectively(1). Air samples taken from the Love Canal region, Niagara Falls, NY in July 1978 resulted in 2 of 3 samples being positive (1.6 and 3.4 ppb), and home basement levels estimated at 0.83 ppb(2). Waste disposal site in Edison, NJ showed trichloroethylene concentrations ranging from a trace-61 ppb(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Trichloroethylene was not detected in sediment in the vicinity of a specialty chemicals plant(1). The compound was detected in marine sediments from Liverpool Bay, England at a max of 9.9 ppb(2). As fo 1985, it has been reported in the USEPA STORET database, based on 338 data points where 6.0% were reported positive, at <5.0 ppb median concentration(3). Trichloroethylene was detected in sediment from Lake Pontchartrain at Passes; from 3 sites, 66.7% were positive at a concentration of 0.1-0.2 ppb, wet weight(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: SOIL: Average concentrations of trichloroethylene in a pine and agricultural soil from a rural site in The Netherlands ranged from 0.08 to 0.8 and <0.01 to 0.06 ug/kg dry weight, respectively(1). Trichloroethylene was detected in 10-11% of 705 samples from 30 industrial sites in samples taken in 1999 in Taiwan(2). Trichloroethylene was detected at 77-5036 and not detected-3371 ng/g in soil samples from superfund sites in Kent, WA and Portland, OR, respectively(3).

StringWithMarkup.String: Global atmospheric emission fluxes of trichloroethylene were reported in 1988 to 1992 with values ranging from 197 to 241 kt/year(1). The global concentration of trichloroethylene has been reported as averaging 8 parts/trillion; the range in the Northern hemisphere is 15-16 parts/trillion and in the Southern hemisphere, <3 parts/trillion(2,3). Concentrations in major USA cities have been reported at a mean concentration of 96-483 parts/trillion, with a maximum of 236-3097 parts/trillion, and a minimum of 5-36 parts/trillion(4,5). Sampling studies conducted in Portland, OR, from Feb-Apr 1984, showed a concentration in air (ng/cu m) during 7 rain events as follows: 100% pos, 240-3900, 1537 average(10). Industrial area concentrations have been reported at a 1.2 ppb mean; urban/suburban- 0.25 ppb mean, and rural trace-0.10 ppb(6-8). Results from a study based in England are as follows: industrial 40-60 ppb, suburban 1-20 ppb, rural 5 ppb(9).

Reference: (1) Evans GF et al; J Air Waste Manage Assoc 42: 1319-23 (1992)

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: Trichloroethylene was detected at >0.10 ppbv in 32% of air samples collected at 10 different locations in Boston, Chicago, Houston and the Seattle/Tacoma area in 1988/1989 as part of the Toxic Air Monitoring System network(1). Trichloroethylene was detected in 14.6% of air samples collected outside 50 homes in the Los Angeles area(2). Mean concentrations of 1.0 (n = 103) and 2.1 (n = 83) ug/cu m were reported in air samples collected from 1986 to 1990 in Southeast Chicago and East St. Louis, respectively(3). Air samples collected as part of the Urban Baseline VOC Measurement Program in the District of Columbia from March 1990 to March 1991 contained trichloroethylene in 66.07% of the samples at a mean concentration of 0.33 ppbv (range 0.17-2.83 ppbv)(4). Yearly mean concentrations of trichloroethylene across several Canadian cities in 1990 and in the US were 0.28 and 6.0 ug/cu m, respectively(5). Air samples collected between 1994 and 1996 at a site in Phoenix, AZ and at Tucson, AZ contained trichloroethylene at average concentrations of 0.05 (range 0.00 to 0.26 ppbv) and 0.04 ppbv (range 0.00 to 0.25 ppbv), respectively(6). Trichloroethylene was measured in air samples collected from urban and suburban locations in Chicago at average concentrations of 0.82-1.16 and 0.52 ug/cu m, respectively(7). The national VOC database, representing 300 cities from 42 states, reports outdoor air samples (n = 3021) contained trichloroethylene at average and median concentrations of 0.495 and 0.158 ppbv, respectively (data reported up to 1985)(8). Trichloroethylene was found in outside air in Minneapolis, MN at concentrations of 0.0-1.0 ug/cu m in 62.5% of samples in winter and at concentrations of 0.1-0.7 ug/cu m in 80.0% of samples in spring 2000(9). Trichloroethylene was detected in 1 of 13 samples taken in US cities (3 in LA, 4 in TX, 5 in VT, 1 in NJ) from Sept 1996 to Aug 1997 at >5 but <10 ppbv(10). Trichloroethylene was measured in 2507 samples in urban/suburban and rural/remote locations throughout MN, it was detected in 2284 (detection limit 0.04 ug/cu m), the mean concentration was 0.43 ug/cu m in positive samples(11). Outdoor atmospheric concentrations of trichloroethylene for 46 students from Philip Randolph Academy in Harlem, New York City were 0.36 and 0.24 ug/cu m in the winter and summer respectively(12).

Reference: (1) Pfeffer H-U; Sci Total Environ 146/147: 263-73 (1994)
(2) Grosjean E et al; Environ Sci Technol 33: 1970-78 (1999)
(3) Alonso L et al; J Air Waste Manage Assoc 49: 916-24 (1999)
(4) Otson R, Fellin P; pp. 335-421 in Gaseous Pollutants: Characterization and Cycling, Nriagu JO, ed. NY, NY: John Wiley Sons, Inc, Chp 9 (1992)
(5) Sakai K et al; Environ Res 94: 75-85 (2004)
(6) Chang C-C et al; Environ Sci Technol 35: 3273-9 (2001)

StringWithMarkup.String: URBAN/SUBURBAN: Trichloroethylene was detected in air samples set up by the North Rhine-Westphalia State Centre for Air Quality Control and Noise Abatement (76 stationary stations and 8 mobile monitoring stations); annual average concentrations in 1990 ranged from 0.17 to 0.62 ug/cu m(1). Air samples collected in Porto Alegre, Brazil from March 1996 to April 1997 contained trichloroethylene at an average concentration of 0.367 ppb (range = 0.1-1.2 ppb, n = 23, 6 samples at detection limit of 0.1 ppb)(2). Air samples collected in Bilbao, Spain in March 1996 contained trichloroethylene at a mean concentration of 0.7 ppbV(3). A maximum outdoor air concentration of <2 ug/cu m was reported in a study of 300 Dutch homes(4). Trichloroethylene was detected in 37 Nagoya, Japan outdoor air samples taken Feb 1998 at 1.79 ug/cu m and in 27 Uppsala, Sweden samples taken Feb to May 1998 at 0.10 ug/cu m(5). Trichloroethylene was detected in 54% of 42 samples taken Sept 2000 in an industrial park area of Taiwan(6).

Reference: (1) Otson R, Fellin P; pp. 335-421 in Gaseous Pollutants: Characterization and Cycling, Nriagu JO, ed, NY, NY: John Wiley & Sons, Inc, Chp 9 (1992)
(2) Hartwell TD et al; Atmos Environ 26A: 1519-27 (1992)

StringWithMarkup.String: INDOOR: An emission rate of 3.6 ug/sq m/hr was measured for the release of trichloroethylene from linoleum tile(1). A summary of US studies monitoring VOCs in indoor air reports that trichloroethylene has been measured at an average concentration of 1.347 ppb in 2134 measurements(1). Trichloroethylene was detected in 50% of air samples collected from the kitchens of 50 homes in the Los Angeles area(2). Indoor air samples from nonsmoking and smoking homes contained trichloroethylene at mean concentrations of 1.84 (range of 0.00 to 9.08 ug/cu m) and 0.66 (range of 0.00 to 3.41 ug/cu m) ug/cu m, respectively(3). Air samples collected from a newly constructed office facility in 1987/1988 contained trichloroethylene at concentrations of 16.4, 7.2, 58.2, and 14.8 ug/cu m at four different sampling events; air samples collected from the roof contained this compound at 0.9 ug/cu m(4). Trichloroethylene was detected in 27% of indoor air samples from 26 "sick" houses at concentrations ranging from not detected to 4.30 ug/cu m; 50 "normal" houses contained trichloroethylene at mean and median concentrations of 0.97 and 0.25 ug/cu m (max = 20.38 ug/cu m)(5). Trichloroethylene was found in 72.9% of samples taken inside two Minneapolis, MN schools during the winter of 2000 at concentrations of 0.1-0.8 ug/cu m, and in 55.6% of samples taken in the same schools in the spring of 2000 at concentrations of 0.0-0.3 ug/cu m(6). Trichloroethylene was found in 82.8 and 73.7% of samples taken in the homes of students associated with the schools at concentrations of 0.1-0.9 and 0.1-1.7 ug/cu m in the winter and spring of 2000, respectively(6). Air samples taken in the Boston Exposure Assessment Microenvironments study had geometric means of 0.43 and 0.23 ug/cu m in retail stores and dining areas for samples taken the summer of 2003 and winter of 2004 and 2005(7). Indoor atmospheric concentrations of trichloroethylene for 46 students from Philip Randolph Academy in Harlem, New York City were 1.26 and 0.32 ug/cu m in the winter and summer respectively(8).

StringWithMarkup.String: Trichloroethylene was detected in the following food samples: intermediates grain-based food (1984): 9 varieties, 44.4% pos, 0.77-2.7 ppb, 1.9 ppb (max concentration in yellow corn meal; wheat, corn, oats (1984)), 10, 2, and 1 samples, respectively: not detected(1). Sampling table-ready foods showed trichloroethylene concentrations as follows: 19 varieties, 47% pos, 1.7-8.0 ppb, 1.5 ppb avg, max concentration in plain granola; butter, 7 samples, 100% pos; 1.6-20 ppb, 9.7 ppb avg; margarine, 7 samples, 100% pos, 3.7-980 ppb, 4.3 ppb avg of pos, max concentration in Mozzarella cheese(2). Trace amounts of trichloroethylene were detected in extracted edible oils(1). It was also detected in meat, beverages, dairy products, fruits and vegetables, oil and fats, range 0.02-60 ug/kg(1). Concentrations of trichloroethylene in food samples were as follows: Cheshire cheese: 3 mg/kg; English butter: 10 mg/kg; eggs: 0.6 mg/kg; shin of beef: 16 mg/kg; beef fat: 12 mg/kg; pig liver: 22 mg/kg; margarine: 6 mg/kg; olive oil (Spanish): 9 mg/kg; cod liver oil: 19 mg/kg; vegetable oil for frying: 7 mg/kg; fruit juices: 5 mg/kg; light beer: 0.7 mg/kg; freeze-dried coffee: 4 mg/kg; tea in bags: 60 mg/kg; Yugoslavian wine: 0.02; potatoes: 3 mg/kg; apples: 5 mg/kg; pears: 5 mg/kg; fresh bread: 7 mg/kg(3).

Reference: (1) Daft JL; J Agric Food Chem 37: 560-64 (1989)
(2) Page BD, LaCroix GM; J AOAC Internat 78: 1416-28 (1995)
(3) Rembold H et al; J Agric Food Chem 37: 659-62 (1989)

StringWithMarkup.String: Trichloroethylene was detected in 5 of 372 samples of food obtained from the Food and Drug Administration's "market basket" collections at concentrations of 2-94 ng/g (mean = 49 ng/g)(1). Trichloroethylene was present in samples of butter from not detected to 0.3 ug/kg, in margarine at concentrations from not detected to 0.4 ug/kg, in peanut butter at concentrations from not detected to 0.7 ug/kg, and in pastry mix at a concentration of 0.2 ug/kg(2). Floured chickpeas contained trichloroethylene at unreported concentrations(3). Trichloroethylene has been reported as a component of chicken meat volatiles(4).

Reference: (1) Fleming-Jones ME, Smith RE; J Agric Food Chem 51: 8120-7 (2003)

StringWithMarkup.String: Trichloroethylene was detected in the following foods during the US FDA total diet program that was run 1996 to 2000 with samplings done four times a year(1).[Table#396]

StringWithMarkup.String: According to the US FDA total diet program that was run 1996 to 2000 with samplings done four times a year, trichloroethylene was not detected in graham crackers, sour cream, olive/safflower oil, sugar cookies, fruit flavored sherbert, popsicle, sandwich cookies, scrambled eggs, raw strawberries, carbonated cola beverage and pork bacon.

StringWithMarkup.String: Tree cores obtained from bald cypress, tupelo, sweet gum, oak, sycamore, and loblolly pine growing over shallow groundwater contaminated with trichloroethylene contained this compound at concentrations from <50 to 35,040 nmol/L (n = 138, sampled January-February 1998, Savannah River Site, SC)(1). Trichloroethylene was detected in 15 of 103 fruit samples taken in 2001 in the area surrounding Hill Air Force Base in Utah at 0.4-17.9 ug/kg fresh weight, but not detected in 257 or 149 fruit samples taken in the same area in 2002 and 2003, respectively(2). Trichloroethylene was detected in 13 of 64, 10 of 58 and 93 of 264 tree bore samples at 0.4-7.5, 0.6-62 and 0.4-204 ug/kg fresh weight, respectively,  from walnut and apple trees growing in the same area of Utah; sampling was conducted in 2001, 2002 and 2003, respectively(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: Clams collected in 1995/1996 from the Ariho, Koe and Okita Rivers, Japan, did not contain measurable quantities of trichloroethylene (detection limit <0.5 ug/kg)(1). Earthworms collected from a forest site adjacent to a former landfill site and chemical plant in West Germany during 1989 contained trichloroethylene at concentrations below detection (detection limit not reported) to 170 ng/g wet weight(2). In a sampling study conducted near Liverpool Bay, UK, trichloroethylene concentrations in Alca torda (Razorbill Auk), Uria aalge (Guillemot), and Rissa tridactyla (Kittiwake) sea bird eggs were 23-33 mg/kg(3). StringWithMarkup.String: Trichloroethylene was found in 2.2% of 1159 household products; automotive products (0.1% weight/weight, 1.2% positive hits in category), household cleaner/polishes (0.0%, 0.9%), paint-related products (3.0%, 1.1%), fabric and leather treatments (0.0%, 2.2%), cleaners for electronic equipment (0.3%, 1.4%), oils, greases and lubricants (0.3%, 1.8%), adhesive-related products (34.7%, 2.6%) and miscellaneous products (33.9%, 14.1%)(1). Household cleaning agents and pesticides contained trichloroethylene at an average concentration of 7 ug/cu m (2). Trichloroethylene was identified in 3 of 26 samples of hobby glue at 0.007 to 0.15 weight percent(3). In the European Community, trichloroethylene is used by some producers during the decaffeinating of coffee(4). Trichloroethylene was detected on lava gas from Etna at 0.02-1.8 ppbv and was detected in fumaroles at 0.07, 0.04, 0.23-0.40 and 0.02-2.2 ppbv from Kuju, Iwojima, Vulcano and Etna volcanos, respectively(5).

StringWithMarkup.String: Trichloroethylene when present in air near open arc welding may be decomposed to levels of phosgene dangerous to health, whereas the HCl and Cl2 formed simultaneously may not always provide an adequate warning against the presence of phosgene.

Reference: Gosselin, R.E., R.P. Smith, H.C. Hodge. Clinical Toxicology of Commercial Products. 5th ed. Baltimore: Williams and Wilkins, 1984., p. II-165

StringWithMarkup.String: Many industrial workers, operating room personnel and dentists are regularly exposed to /trichloroethylene/, some to large doses. The general public encounters trichloroethylene in cleaning fluids, some decaffeinated coffees and spice extracts.

StringWithMarkup.String: According to the 2006 TSCA Inventory Update Report, the number of workers reasonably likely to be exposed in the industrial manufacturing, processing, and use for trichloroethylene is 1000 or greater persons; the data may be greatly underestimated(1).

Reference: (1) NIOSH; NOES. National Occupational Exposure Survey conducted from 1981-1983. Estimated numbers of employees potentially exposed to specific agents by 2-digit standard industrial classification (SIC). Available from, as of Sept 30, 2010: https://www.cdc.gov/noes/

StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 401,373 workers (175,316 of these were female) were potentially exposed to trichloroethylene in the US(1). Occupational exposure to trichloroethylene may occur through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where trichloroethylene is produced or used. Monitoring data indicate that the general population may be exposed to trichloroethylene via inhalation of ambient air, ingestion of food and drinking water, and dermal contact with this compound or other consumer products containing trichloroethylene(SRC).

StringWithMarkup.String: PERSONAL AIR: The exhaled breath of 73% of 26 smokers and 81% of 43 nonsmokers contained trichloroethylene at unreported concentrations(1). Breath of 12.5% of 50 individuals living in the Los Angeles area contained trichloroethylene(2). 51.2% of personal air samples collected from these 50 individuals contained trichloroethylene(2). Increased personal air exposures were reported following solvent use, household cleaning, furniture stripping, visiting a dry cleaning shop, photo developing and using paint remover of up to 220 ug/cu m from a baseline of <2 ug/cu m(3). Personal air samples from Los Angeles and Contra Costa residents contained trichloroethylene at concentrations of 7.8 ug/cu m (n = 110, Los Angeles residents, February 1984), 6.4 ug/cu m (n = 50, Los Angeles residents, May 1984) and 3.8 ug/cu m (n = 67, Contra Costa residents, June 1984)(4).

Reference: (1) Adgate JL et al; Environ Health Perspect 112: 1386-92 (2004)
(2) Dodson RE et al; Environ Sci Technol 41(24): 8498-505 (2007)
(3) Hoffmann K et al; J Expo Anal Environ Epidemiol 10: 115-25 (2000)
(4) Kinney PL et al; Environ Health Perspect 110: 539-46 (2002)
(5) Sexton K et al; Environ Sci Technol 38: 2593-602 (2004)

StringWithMarkup.String: PERSONAL AIR: Personal air samples taken on 113 inner city school kids in Minneapolis, MN contained trichloroethylene in 90.3 and 72.7% at concentrations of 0.1-0.8 ug/cu m from samples taken in both the winter and spring of 2000(1). Personal air samples taken in the Boston Exposure Assessment Microenvironments study had a geometric mean of 0.17 ug/cu m in 55 nonsmoking participants, working in nonmanufacturing jobs, living in and around the greater Boston area, samples taken the summer of 2003 and winter of 2004 and 2005(2). Badge samplers worn for one week by 113 adults in 1990 and 1991 found trichloroethylene at an arithmetic mean of 2.7 and geometric mean of 1.2 ug/cu m(3). Personal air concentrations of trichloroethylene for 46 students from Philip Randolph Academy in Harlem, New York City were 2.62 and 0.51 ug/cu m in the winter and summer respectively(4). Personal air samples taken on 25 people from Battle Creek, 22 people from East St Paul and 24 people from Phillips contained an average of 0.2 ug/cu m on samples taken the spring and fall of 1999(5).

Reference: (1) Brugnone F et al; Med Lav 85: 370-89 (1994)
(2) Kender LJ et al; Arch Environ Hlth 46: 174-78 (1991)
(3) Kroneld R; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 42: 873-77 (1989)
(4) Onstot JD, Stanley JS; Identification of SARA Compounds in Adipose Tissue. Washington DC: US EPS, Office of Toxic Substances, USEPA-560/5-89-003 (1989)
(5) Nakahama T et al; Jpn J Toxicol Environ Hlth; 43: 280-84 (1997)
(6) Wallace LA et al; Atmos Environ 22: 2141-63 (1988)

StringWithMarkup.String: Blood samples from 179 of 277 people from the general population contained trichloroethylene at a mean concentration of 458 ng/L; a mean blood concentration of 763 ng/L was reported from 63 of 113 urban workers as compared to 180 ng/L from 82 of 127 workers(1). Blood samples collected from workers exposed to trichloroethylene in 4 dry-cleaning shops (air concentrations ranged from 25-40 ppm) contained this compound (median = 3.39 umol/L after work (range 0.46-12.71), 0.38 umol/L before work (range = 0.15-3.58)(2). Urine samples from the same workers contained the trichloroethylene metabolite, trichloroethanol (median 54.89 umol/mol creatine, range 5.30-177.67 after work; median = 9.70 umol/mol creatine, range 0.38-35.65 before work)(2). Kidney (n = 9), lung (n = 13), and muscle (n = 16) tissues collected from humans in Turku, Finland in 1987 contained trichloroethylene at 0.7, 0.02, and 0.2 ug/kg, respectively(3). Trichloroethylene was detected in 20% of composite adipose tissue samples collected in FY82 (n 46 composite samples)(4). Breathing air samples from 30 residents of Tokyo, Japan had a mean concentration of 2.0 ug/cu m trichloroethylene with a calculated daily intake due to breathing ambient air of 40 ug/person (men 24.9 ug/person; women 51.5 ug/person)(5). Breath samples of Los Angeles and Contra Costa residents contained trichloroethylene at concentrations of 1.6 (n = 110, Los Angeles residents, February 1984), 1.0 (n = 50, Los Angeles residents, May 1984) and 0.6 ug/L (n = 67, Contra Costa residents, June 1984)(6).

Literature references related to scientific contents from Springer Nature journals and books. These references have been ranked automatically by an algorithm which calculates the relevance for each substance in a Springer Nature document. It is based on: (1) the TF-IDF, adapted to chemical structures, (2) location information in the text (e.g. title, abstract, keywords), and (3) the document size.  Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

Chemical co-occurrences in literature highlight chemicals mentioned together in scientific articles. This may suggest that an important relationship exists between the two. Please note that this content is not human curated. It is generated by text-mining algorithms that can be fooled such that a co-occurrence may be happenstance or a casual mention. The lists are ordered by relevancy as indicated by count of publications and other statistics, with the most relevant mentions appearing at the top.

Section.Description: A set of concepts and categories in a subject area or domain that shows their properties and the relations between them.

ChEBI Ontology tree.  ChEBI is an acronym for Chemical Entities of Biological Interest, which is a freely available dictionary of molecular entities focused on 'small' chemical compounds. ChEBI incorporates an ontological classification, whereby the relationships between molecular entities or classes of entities and their parents and/or children are specified.
Anatomical Therapeutic Chemical (ATC) classification tree from the Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG).

The Anatomical Therapeutic Chemical (ATC) Classification System is used for the classification of drugs. This pharmaceutical coding system divides drugs into different groups according to the organ or system on which they act and/or their therapeutic and chemical characteristics. Each bottom-level ATC code stands for a pharmaceutically used substance, or a combination of substances, in a single indication (or use). This means that one drug can have more than one code: acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin), for example, has A01AD05 as a drug for local oral treatment, B01AC06 as a platelet inhibitor, and N02BA01 as an analgesic and antipyretic. On the other hand, several different brands share the same code if they have the same active substance and indications.

Classification of this compound, provided by ChemIDplus, which is a free web search system that provides access to the structure and nomenclature authority files used for the identification of chemical substances cited in National Library of Medicine (NLM) databases.  ChemIDplus groups chemicals based on the source locators (i.e., what information resources have data for a given chemical).

CAMEO chemical reactivity classification from CAMEO Chemicals, which is a database of hazardous chemical datasheets that emergency responders and planners can use to get response recommendations and predict hazards (e.g., explosions or toxic fumes).
Classification of this entity in the context of targets, provided by ChEMBL.

The United Nations' Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labelling of Chemicals (GHS) provides a harmonized basis for globally uniform physical, environmental, and health and safety information on hazardous chemical substances and mixtures.

Classification from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's CPDat (Chemical and Products Database).  This database contains information mapping more than 49,000 chemicals to a set of terms categorizing their usage or function in 16,000 consumer products (e.g. shampoo, soap) types based on what chemicals they contain.
A classification from the NORMAN Suspect List Exchange, which serve as a central access point to find lists of chemicals with environmental concerns.

Classification from the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Distributed Structure-Searchable Toxicity (DSSTox) database. DSSTox provides a high quality public chemistry resource for supporting improved predictive toxicology. A distinguishing feature of this effort is the accurate mapping of bioassay and physicochemical property data associated with chemical substances to their corresponding chemical structures.

Reference.Description: The USGS Health-Based Screening Levels for Evaluating Water-Quality Data contains Health-Based Screening Levels (HBSLs) that are non-enforceable water-quality benchmarks that can be used to (1) supplement U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Maximum Contaminant Levels (MCLs) and Human Health Benchmarks for Pesticides (HHBPs), (2) determine whether contaminants found in surface-water or groundwater sources of drinking water may indicate a potential human-health concern, and (3) help prioritize monitoring efforts. HBSLs were developed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS).

Reference.Name: GHS Classification Tree
Reference.Description: The United Nations' Globally Harmonized System of Classification and Labeling of Chemicals (GHS) provides a harmonized basis for globally uniform physical, environmental, and health and safety information on hazardous chemical substances and mixtures. Please note that obsolete codes are added in this classification for completeness purposes, as they are still in use. Any obsolete codes are annotated as such.

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
Reference.LicenseNote: CC-BY 4.0
